'speaker_8': 'Thank you, Tom. Mayor, members of the city council. I want to thank Jim McMillan and the association. 'speaker_8': 'As you know, this this amendment actually takes us through June 30th of 2028. So just before the Olympics are anticipated to be here in Long Beach, the city and the city council asked that we retain rights to develop portions of the race circuit if needed, that would include surrounding areas that might displace or cause disruption of the'

'speaker_8': 'race track as it currently sits. So there are a number of conditions in this new agreement that allow for us to involve the associations and notify and then work together throughout that process in the event that the city needs the rights to develop that lot.'

'speaker_8': 'Additionally, the Mayor and City Council asked the association to reduce, set up and tear down time. And so with this new term, which starts January of 2023, for those races, the set of time will be reduced from 53 down to 50 day days for setup and 21 to 20 days on on tear down.'

'speaker_8': 'So that's another 5% reduction of set up and tear down time. We needed to maintain safety, of course, and ensure that the inspection process ensured the safety of both guests as well as participants in the race. So additionally, we've maintained and improved on construction timing.'

'speaker_8': 'There will be no street improvements or street decoration before 7 a.m. in the morning or after six p. We want to make sure that adjacent residential and businesses are not impacted negatively. And there are also additional inspections that will occur beginning in advance of actually the 22 race.'

'speaker_8': 'So this race that's happening in April, we will be doing additional pre-race inspections of the roads to ensure that anything that is impacted with regard to tire marks or or other blemishes, that that those are detailed and ultimately addressed.'

'speaker_8': 'And following the race, there will also be a full grind and overlay of Pine Avenue prior to the 2023 race, which will repair the area on Pine Avenue between Seaside Way and Shoreline Drive. We also will have what's called an emulsion treatment, which will, for all the asphalt areas, make it look like new to make sure that'

'speaker_8': 'we establish a new standard after the 22 race, after this April race, so that we have a very attractive environment for our our entertainment district. There will also be, from the association, a annual road restoration contribution of $30,000 per year for the period of five years.'

'speaker_8': 'That'll be $150,000, which will go to public works and in the city to continue to maintain that standard. That's established after this next 20, 2022 race. 'speaker_8': 'though the association experienced financial hardship over the past two years. They will pay all their fees. We will be spreading those over the next few years. But the association has is continuing to make those payments and and will continue to do so in this new agreement.'
